title: Centuries-Old English Country House on the Market With an Upgrade
text:
A unique property in the middle of the charming English countryside enclave of the Cotswolds that has married its more than 400-year history with contemporary design hit the market earlier this week.



Known as Home Farm, the five-bedroom property—which dates back to the late 1500s—is asking £2.9 million (US$3.56 million.)



More: For a Safer Bet in a Tough Luxury Market, Consider the Penthouse

The Grade II-listed property, a former monk’s presbytery, underwent a four-year redesign by architect De Matos Ryan, who has also worked on the British Library in London and is currently renovating The V&A Museum of Childhood.



Given the historic listing, which restricts alterations, the emphasis of the redesign was on restoring the original building whilst creating a modern wing that dramatically expanded the living space, according to the listing with The Modern House.



"The restoration allowed the owners to specify thoughtful modern additions that elevated the original building, with particular focus on creating a sustainable modern home that celebrated the protected heritage," the brokerage said in a statement.



As part of the project, the stone roof tiles were recreated and replaced, all the windows were replaced with appropriate flat-lead alternatives, new handmade guttering was installed and underfloor heating was laid to avoid the installation of modern radiators, according to the listing.



From Penta: Preparing Napa Valley Wine for Climate Change

When completed in 2011, the house won a Roses Design Award and was shortlisted for two other design awards.



The resulting property has exposed brick, beams and stone floors, along with all the convenience and design of a modern home.



There’s a dining room with a reconditioned stone spiral staircase along with a master suite complete with an en-suite bathroom with an oversized rain shower, and a separate dressing room.



The newly added structure holds the open-plan kitchen area and has a limestone floor that echoes the materials used in the old house and sliding walls of glass that open onto the garden.



Mansion Global could not determine the owners of the home, or how much they paid for it.
